question: Socrates is of opinion that a man must be mad who behaves in this [MASK] at a festival when he is surrounded by his friends and there is nothing to trouble him.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: Ion is delighted at the notion of being inspired, and acknowledges that he is beside himself when he is performing;--his eyes rain tears and his hair stands on end.
next_sentence: Ion is confident that Socrates would never think him mad if he could only hear his embellishments of Homer.

question: Would he rather be regarded as inspired or [MASK]? '
title: Ion

question: The greatest strength is observed to have an [MASK] of limitation.
title: Ion

question: For if he does not know the [MASK], neither will he know the good when the same topic is being discussed.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: SOCRATES: And speaking generally, in all discussions in which the subject is the same and many men are speaking, will not he who knows the good know the bad speaker also?
next_sentence: ION: True.

question: 'What about things of which he has no [MASK]? '
title: Ion
prev_sentence: 'Yes, indeed he can.'
next_sentence: Ion answers that he can interpret anything in Homer.

question: The poets and their interpreters may be compared to a [MASK] of magnetic rings suspended from one another, and from a magnet.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The solution given by Socrates is as follows:--  The rhapsode is not guided by rules of art, but is an inspired person who derives a mysterious power from the poet; and the poet, in like manner, is inspired by the God.
next_sentence: The magnet is the Muse, and the ring which immediately follows is the poet himself; from him are suspended other poets; there is also a chain of rhapsodes and actors, who also hang from the Muses, but are let down at the side; and the last ring of all is the spectator.

question: This is confirmed by the [MASK] of sculpture, painting, flute-playing, and the other arts.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: And poetry is a whole; and he who judges of poetry by rules of art ought to be able to judge of all poetry.'
next_sentence: The argument is at last brought home to the mind of Ion, who asks how this contradiction is to be solved.

question: For the rhapsode ought to interpret the mind of the poet to his [MASK], but how can he interpret him well unless he knows what he means?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: And no man can be a rhapsode who does not understand the meaning of the poet.
next_sentence: All this is greatly to be envied.

question: All this is greatly to be [MASK].
title: Ion
prev_sentence: For the rhapsode ought to interpret the mind of the poet to his hearers, but how can he interpret him well unless he knows what he means?
next_sentence: ION: Very true, Socrates; interpretation has certainly been the most laborious part of my art; and I believe myself able to speak about Homer better than any man; and that neither Metrodorus of Lampsacus, nor Stesimbrotus of Thasos, nor Glaucon, nor any one else who ever was, had as good ideas about Homer as I have, or as many.

question: Ion is delighted at the notion of being inspired, and acknowledges that he is beside himself when he is performing ;--his eyes [MASK] tears and his hair stands on end.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The poet is the inspired interpreter of the God, and this is the reason why some poets, like Homer, are restricted to a single theme, or, like Tynnichus, are famous for a single poem; and the rhapsode is the inspired interpreter of the poet, and for a similar reason some rhapsodes, like Ion, are the interpreters of single poets.
next_sentence: Socrates is of opinion that a man must be mad who behaves in this way at a festival when he is surrounded by his friends and there is nothing to trouble him.

question: And no man can be a rhapsode who does not understand the [MASK] of the poet.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: Then, again, you are obliged to be continually in the company of many good poets; and especially of Homer, who is the best and most divine of them; and to understand him, and not merely learn his words by rote, is a thing greatly to be envied.
next_sentence: For the rhapsode ought to interpret the mind of the poet to his hearers, but how can he interpret him well unless he knows what he means?

question: The elements of a true theory of poetry are contained in the notion that the [MASK] is inspired.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The Ion, like the other earlier Platonic Dialogues, is a mixture of jest and earnest, in which no definite result is obtained, but some Socratic or Platonic truths are allowed dimly to appear.
next_sentence: Genius is often said to be unconscious, or spontaneous, or a gift of nature: that 'genius is akin to madness' is a popular aphorism of modern times.

question: For the poet is a light and winged and holy thing, and there is no invention in him until he has been inspired and is out of his senses, and the mind is no longer in him: when he has not [MASK] to this state, he is powerless and is unable to utter his oracles.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: And this is true.
next_sentence: Many are the noble words in which poets speak concerning the actions of men; but like yourself when speaking about Homer, they do not speak of them by any rules of art: they are simply inspired to utter that to which the Muse impels them, and that only; and when inspired, one of them will make dithyrambs, another hymns of praise, another choral strains, another epic or iambic verses--and he who is good at one is not good at any other kind of verse: for not by art does the poet sing, but by power divine.

question: Your heads and your faces and your limbs underneath are shrouded in night; and the voice of [MASK] bursts forth, and your cheeks are wet with tears.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: what is happening to you?
next_sentence: And the vestibule is full, and the court is full, of ghosts descending into the darkness of Erebus, and the sun has perished out of heaven, and an evil mist is spread abroad (Od.).'

question: The grace and [MASK] of this little work supply the only, and perhaps a sufficient, proof of its genuineness.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The Ion is the shortest, or nearly the shortest, of all the writings which bear the name of Plato, and is not authenticated by any early external testimony.
next_sentence: The plan is simple; the dramatic interest consists entirely in the contrast between the irony of Socrates and the transparent vanity and childlike enthusiasm of the rhapsode Ion.

question: Let us consider this matter; is not the art of [MASK] a whole?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: For consider what a very commonplace and trivial thing is this which I have said--a thing which any man might say: that when a man has acquired a knowledge of a whole art, the enquiry into good and bad is one and the same.
next_sentence: ION: Yes.

question: Sense or passion are too much for the 'dry light' of intelligence which [MASK] with them and becomes discoloured by them.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The greatest strength is observed to have an element of limitation.
next_sentence: Imagination is often at war with reason and fact.

question: Must the same art have the same [MASK] of knowledge, and different arts other subjects of knowledge?
title: Ion

next_sentence: ION: That is my opinion, Socrates.

question: The [MASK] of the mind on a single object, or on a single aspect of human nature, overpowers the orderly perception of the whole.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: Imagination is often at war with reason and fact.
next_sentence: Yet the feelings too bring truths home to the minds of many who in the way of reason would be incapable of understanding them.

question: ),'--will the art of the [MASK] or of the rhapsode be better able to judge whether these lines are rightly expressed or not?

question: Yet the feelings too bring truths home to the minds of many who in the way of reason would be [MASK] of understanding them.
title: Ion

question: Do you [MASK] to say that the art of the rhapsode and of the general is the same?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: SOCRATES: What do you mean?
next_sentence: ION: Yes, one and the same.

question: Genius is often said to be unconscious, or spontaneous, or a gift of nature: that 'genius is akin to madness' is a popular [MASK] of modern times.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The elements of a true theory of poetry are contained in the notion that the poet is inspired.

question: For all good poets, epic as well as lyric, compose their beautiful poems not by art, but because they are inspired and [MASK].
title: Ion
prev_sentence: In like manner the Muse first of all inspires men herself; and from these inspired persons a chain of other persons is suspended, who take the inspiration.
next_sentence: And as the Corybantian revellers when they dance are not in their right mind, so the lyric poets are not in their right mind when they are composing their beautiful strains: but when falling under the power of music and metre they are inspired and possessed; like Bacchic maidens who draw milk and honey from the rivers when they are under the influence of Dionysus but not when they are in their right mind.

question: As he does not know all of them, which of them will he [MASK]?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: SOCRATES: You mean to say that you would exclude pretty much the subjects of the other arts.
next_sentence: ION: He will know what a man and what a woman ought to say, and what a freeman and what a slave ought to say, and what a ruler and what a subject.

question: Imagination is often at [MASK] with reason and fact.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: Sense or passion are too much for the 'dry light' of intelligence which mingles with them and becomes discoloured by them.
next_sentence: The concentration of the mind on a single object, or on a single aspect of human nature, overpowers the orderly perception of the whole.

question: Now would you say that the art of the rhapsode or the art of medicine was better able to judge of the [MASK] of these lines?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: SOCRATES: You know the passage in which Hecamede, the concubine of Nestor, is described as giving to the wounded Machaon a posset, as he says,  'Made with Pramnian wine; and she grated cheese of goat's milk with a grater of bronze, and at his side placed an onion which gives a relish to drink (Il.).'
next_sentence: ION: The art of medicine.

question: Which do you prefer to be thought, dishonest or [MASK]?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: But if, as I believe, you have no art, but speak all these beautiful words about Homer unconsciously under his inspiring influence, then I acquit you of dishonesty, and shall only say that you are inspired.
next_sentence: ION: There is a great difference, Socrates, between the two alternatives; and inspiration is by far the nobler.

question: Even more than the sophist he is incapable of appreciating the commonest [MASK] distinctions; he cannot explain the nature of his own art; his great memory contrasts with his inability to follow the steps of the argument.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The rhapsode belongs to the realm of imitation and of opinion: he professes to have all knowledge, which is derived by him from Homer, just as the sophist professes to have all wisdom, which is contained in his art of rhetoric.
next_sentence: And in his highest moments of inspiration he has an eye to his own gains.

question: Have you already [MASK] what you were saying?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: SOCRATES: Not all, Ion, surely.
next_sentence: A rhapsode ought to have a better memory.

question: and does he not speak of human society and of intercourse of men, good and bad, skilled and unskilled, and of the gods [MASK] with one another and with mankind, and about what happens in heaven and in the world below, and the generations of gods and heroes?
title: Ion
prev_sentence: Is not war his great argument?
next_sentence: Are not these the themes of which Homer sings?

question: And poetry is a whole; and he who judges of poetry by [MASK] of art ought to be able to judge of all poetry . '
title: Ion
prev_sentence: 'And yet, surely, he who knows the superior ought to know the inferior also;--he who can judge of the good speaker is able to judge of the bad.

question: And in his highest moments of inspiration he has an eye to his own [MASK].

prev_sentence: Even more than the sophist he is incapable of appreciating the commonest logical distinctions; he cannot explain the nature of his own art; his great memory contrasts with his inability to follow the steps of the argument.
next_sentence: The old quarrel between philosophy and poetry, which in the Republic leads to their final separation, is already working in the mind of Plato, and is embodied by him in the contrast between Socrates and Ion.

question: This stone not only attracts iron rings, but also imparts to them a similar power of attracting other rings; and sometimes you may see a number of [MASK] of iron and rings suspended from one another so as to form quite a long chain: and all of them derive their power of suspension from the original stone.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: The gift which you possess of speaking excellently about Homer is not an art, but, as I was just saying, an inspiration; there is a divinity moving you, like that contained in the stone which Euripides calls a magnet, but which is commonly known as the stone of Heraclea.
next_sentence: In like manner the Muse first of all inspires men herself; and from these inspired persons a chain of other persons is suspended, who take the inspiration.

question: If you were able to [MASK] of him by rules of art, you would have been able to speak of all other poets; for poetry is a whole.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: No one can fail to see that you speak of Homer without any art or knowledge.
next_sentence: ION: Yes.

question: 'No, that is not the real [MASK]; there are many examples to the contrary.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: Ion replies that he is a foreigner, and the Athenians and Spartans will not appoint a foreigner to be their general.
next_sentence: But Ion has long been playing tricks with the argument; like Proteus, he transforms himself into a variety of shapes, and is at last about to run away in the disguise of a general.

question: The rhapsode like yourself and the actor are intermediate [MASK], and the poet himself is the first of them.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: SOCRATES: Do you know that the spectator is the last of the rings which, as I am saying, receive the power of the original magnet from one another?

question: He still [MASK], however, that he understands the art of the general as well as any one.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: Ion is compelled to admit that every man will judge of his own particular art better than the rhapsode.
next_sentence: 'Then why in this city of Athens, in which men of merit are always being sought after, is he not at once appointed a general?'

question: 'And yet, surely, he who [MASK] the superior ought to know the inferior also ;--he who can judge of the good speaker is able to judge of the bad.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: In the course of conversation the admission is elicited from Ion that his skill is restricted to Homer, and that he knows nothing of inferior poets, such as Hesiod and Archilochus;--he brightens up and is wide awake when Homer is being recited, but is apt to go to sleep at the recitations of any other poet.
next_sentence: And poetry is a whole; and he who judges of poetry by rules of art ought to be able to judge of all poetry.'

question: Ion is compelled to admit that every man will [MASK] of his own particular art better than the rhapsode.
title: Ion
prev_sentence: But, rejoins Socrates, when Homer speaks of the arts, as for example, of chariot-driving, or of medicine, or of prophecy, or of navigation--will he, or will the charioteer or physician or prophet or pilot be the better judge?
next_sentence: He still maintains, however, that he understands the art of the general as well as any one.

question: Then, do you [MASK] any way in which the philosopher can be preserved in his calling to the end?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: That is evident.
next_sentence: and remember what we were saying of him, that he was to have quickness and memory and courage and magnificence--these were admitted by us to be the true philosopher's gifts.

question: 'Yes, for then he would have more honour and [MASK]. '
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But if a person could create as well as imitate, he would rather leave some permanent work and not an imitation only; he would rather be the receiver than the giver of praise?
next_sentence: Let us now interrogate Homer and the poets.

question: Neither sight nor the [MASK] in which sight resides is the sun?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: How?

question: And the conclusions drawn from them are sound, although the premises are [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: ), but uses their words and expressions as vehicles of a higher truth; not on a system like Theagenes of Rhegium or Metrodorus, or in later times the Stoics, but as fancy may dictate.
next_sentence: These fanciful appeals to Homer add a charm to Plato's style, and at the same time they have the effect of a satire on the follies of Homeric interpretation.

question: The virtues are based on justice, of which common honesty in buying and selling is the shadow, and justice is based on the idea of good, which is the harmony of the world, and is [MASK] both in the institutions of states and in motions of the heavenly bodies (cp.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And when the constitution of the State is completed, the conception of justice is not dismissed, but reappears under the same or different names throughout the work, both as the inner law of the individual soul, and finally as the principle of rewards and punishments in another life.
next_sentence: Tim.

question: In the first place the guardians must [MASK] from strong drink, for they should be the last persons to lose their wits.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Next we pass on to gymnastics; about which I would remark, that the soul is related to the body as a cause to an effect, and therefore if we educate the mind we may leave the education of the body in her charge, and need only give a general outline of the course to be pursued.
next_sentence: Whether the habits of the palaestra are suitable to them is more doubtful, for the ordinary gymnastic is a sleepy sort of thing, and if left off suddenly is apt to endanger health.

question: Yes, he said, that is the nature of democracy, whether the revolution has been effected by arms, or whether fear has caused the opposite party to [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And then democracy comes into being after the poor have conquered their opponents, slaughtering some and banishing some, while to the remainder they give an equal share of freedom and power; and this is the form of government in which the magistrates are commonly elected by lot.
next_sentence: And now what is their manner of life, and what sort of a government have they?

question: The breeder of animals aims chiefly at size or speed or strength; in a few [MASK] at courage or temper; most often the fitness of the animal for food is the great desideratum.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The human being is regarded with the eye of a dog- or bird-fancier, or at best of a slave-owner; the higher or human qualities are left out.
next_sentence: But mankind are not bred to be eaten, nor yet for their superiority in fighting or in running or in drawing carts.

question: Their habits and their dwellings should correspond to their [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: There let them sacrifice and set up their tents; for soldiers they are to be and not shopkeepers, the watchdogs and guardians of the sheep; and luxury and avarice will turn them into wolves and tyrants.
next_sentence: They should have no property; their pay should only meet their expenses; and they should have common meals.

question: Are not necessary pleasures those of which we cannot get rid, and of which the [MASK] is a benefit to us?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: I should.
next_sentence: And they are rightly called so, because we are framed by nature to desire both what is beneficial and what is necessary, and cannot help it.

question: One woman will be a good [MASK], another not; and the good must be chosen to be the colleagues of our guardians.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Women are the same in kind as men, and have the same aptitude or want of aptitude for medicine or gymnastic or war, but in a less degree.
next_sentence: If however their natures are the same, the inference is that their education must also be the same; there is no longer anything unnatural or impossible in a woman learning music and gymnastic.

question: And therefore you had better [MASK] at once with which of the two you are proposing to argue.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Now there are two classes of persons: one class of those who will agree with you and will take your words as a revelation; another class to whom they will be utterly unmeaning, and who will naturally deem them to be idle tales, for they see no sort of profit which is to be obtained from them.
next_sentence: You will very likely say with neither, and that your chief aim in carrying on the argument is your own improvement; at the same time you do not grudge to others any benefit which they may receive.

question: Let us be consistent then, and [MASK] both or neither.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And even if there are gods, and they do care about us, yet we know of them only from tradition and the genealogies of the poets; and these are the very persons who say that they may be influenced and turned by 'sacrifices and soothing entreaties and by offerings.'
next_sentence: If the poets speak truly, why then we had better be unjust, and offer of the fruits of injustice; for if we are just, although we may escape the vengeance of heaven, we shall lose the gains of injustice; but, if we are unjust, we shall keep the gains, and by our sinning and praying, and praying and sinning, the gods will be propitiated, and we shall not be punished.

question: He speaks in a very interesting manner of the beauty and [MASK] of nature and of the human frame, which he conceives to afford a foretaste of the heavenly state and of the resurrection of the body.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: He dwells at length on miracles performed in his own day, of which the evidence is regarded by him as irresistible.
next_sentence: The book is not really what to most persons the title of it would imply, and belongs to an age which has passed away.

question: The connexions formed between superior and inferior races hardly ever produce a noble [MASK], because they are licentious; and because the children in such cases usually despise the mother and are neglected by the father who is ashamed of them.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The exceptions occurring among Brahmins or Mahometans or the ancient Persians, are of that sort which may be said to prove the rule.
next_sentence: Barbarous nations when they are introduced by Europeans to vice die out; polygamist peoples either import and adopt children from other countries, or dwindle in numbers, or both.

question: Their victims attempt to resist; they are driven mad by the stings of the drones, and so become [MASK] oligarchs in self-defence.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: When the people meet, they are omnipotent, but they cannot be brought together unless they are attracted by a little honey; and the rich are made to supply the honey, of which the demagogues keep the greater part themselves, giving a taste only to the mob.
next_sentence: Then follow informations and convictions for treason.

question: No city, he said, can be more [MASK] enslaved.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Beginning with the State, I replied, would you say that a city which is governed by a tyrant is free or enslaved?
next_sentence: And yet, as you see, there are freemen as well as masters in such a State?

question: Yes, he said, that is the [MASK] way of meeting the attacks of fortune.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: That we should take counsel about what has happened, and when the dice have been thrown order our affairs in the way which reason deems best; not, like children who have had a fall, keeping hold of the part struck and wasting time in setting up a howl, but always accustoming the soul forthwith to apply a remedy, raising up that which is sickly and fallen, banishing the cry of sorrow by the healing art.
next_sentence: Yes, I said; and the higher principle is ready to follow this suggestion of reason?

question: Then let me [MASK] you my view about them.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Yes, I quite understand.
next_sentence: I do not see them, and therefore the distinctions of figure, colour, and the like, which enable me to discern the differences of some things, do not apply to them.

question: He is not one of those who have nothing to say, because their [MASK] mind has been absorbed in making money.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: His love of conversation, his affection, his indifference to riches, even his garrulity, are interesting traits of character.
next_sentence: Yet he acknowledges that riches have the advantage of placing men above the temptation to dishonesty or falsehood.

question: Then the first thing will be to establish a censorship of the writers of fiction, and let the censors receive any tale of [MASK] which is good, and reject the bad; and we will desire mothers and nurses to tell their children the authorised ones only.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: We cannot.
next_sentence: Let them fashion the mind with such tales, even more fondly than they mould the body with their hands; but most of those which are now in use must be discarded.

question: Whereas the simple and moderate desires which follow reason, and are under the guidance of [MASK] and true opinion, are to be found only in a few, and those the best born and best educated.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Certainly, he said.
next_sentence: Very true.

question: Or was any war ever [MASK] on by your counsels?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Is there any city which professes to have received laws from you, as Sicily and Italy have from Charondas, Sparta from Lycurgus, Athens from Solon?
next_sentence: or is any invention attributed to you, as there is to Thales and Anacharsis?

question: What kind or degree of unity is to be [MASK] after in a building, in the plastic arts, in poetry, in prose, is a problem which has to be determined relatively to the subject-matter.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The truth is, that we may as well speak of many designs as of one; nor need anything be excluded from the plan of a great work to which the mind is naturally led by the association of ideas, and which does not interfere with the general purpose.
next_sentence: To Plato himself, the enquiry 'what was the intention of the writer,' or 'what was the principal argument of the Republic' would have been hardly intelligible, and therefore had better be at once dismissed (cp.

question: Admitting that the arts, which some of us almost deify, have fallen short of their [MASK] aim, we must admit on the other hand that to banish imagination wholly would be suicidal as well as impossible.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Plato himself seems to waver between two opposite views--when, as in the third Book, he insists that youth should be brought up amid wholesome imagery; and again in Book X, when he banishes the poets from his Republic.
next_sentence: For nature too is a form of art; and a breath of the fresh air or a single glance at the varying landscape would in an instant revive and reillumine the extinguished spark of poetry in the human breast.

question: You, as legislator, have already [MASK] the men; and now you shall select the women.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: In the first place our rulers will enforce the laws and make new ones where they are wanted, and their allies or ministers will obey.
next_sentence: After the selection has been made, they will dwell in common houses and have their meals in common, and will be brought together by a necessity more certain than that of mathematics.

question: The harmony of the musical scale, which is elsewhere used as a symbol of the harmony of the [MASK], is also indicated.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The lesser or square 'harmony,' of 400, might be a symbol of the guardians,--the larger or oblong 'harmony,' of the people, and the numbers 3, 4, 5 might refer respectively to the three orders in the State or parts of the soul, the four virtues, the five forms of government.
next_sentence: For the numbers 3, 4, 5, which represent the sides of the Pythagorean triangle, also denote the intervals of the scale.

question: No [MASK] enquirer has ever fairly criticised his own speculations; in his own judgment they have been above criticism; nor has he understood that what to him seemed to be absolute truth may reappear in the next generation as a form of logic or an instrument of thought.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The discovery of a great metaphysical conception seems to ravish the mind with a prophetic consciousness which takes away the power of estimating its value.
next_sentence: And posterity have also sometimes equally misapprehended the real value of his speculations.

question: [MASK] differences commonly originate in a disagreement about the use of the terms 'mine' and 'not mine ,' 'his' and 'not his . '
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Certainly.
next_sentence: Exactly so.

question: You mean when money is not wanted, but allowed to [MASK]?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: When you want a deposit to be kept safely.

question: Yes, he replied, the opponent might have something to [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But here a confusion may arise; and I should wish to guard against an opponent starting up and saying that no man desires drink only, but good drink, or food only, but good food; for good is the universal object of desire, and thirst being a desire, will necessarily be thirst after good drink; and the same is true of every other desire.
next_sentence: Nevertheless I should still maintain, that of relatives some have a quality attached to either term of the relation; others are simple and have their correlatives simple.

question: And if he is compelled to look [MASK] at the light, will he not have a pain in his eyes which will make him turn away to take refuge in the objects of vision which he can see, and which he will conceive to be in reality clearer than the things which are now being shown to him?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Far truer.
next_sentence: True, he said.

question: And if there were a contest, and he had to compete in measuring the shadows with the prisoners who had never moved out of the den, while his sight was still weak, and before his eyes had become steady (and the time which would be needed to acquire this new habit of sight might be very [MASK]), would he not be ridiculous?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: To be sure, he said.
next_sentence: Men would say of him that up he went and down he came without his eyes; and that it was better not even to think of ascending; and if any one tried to loose another and lead him up to the light, let them only catch the offender, and they would put him to death.

question: Neither is death terrible to him; and therefore lamentations over the dead should not be practised by [MASK] of note; they should be the concern of inferior persons only, whether women or men.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: A good man is not prostrated at the loss of children or fortune.
next_sentence: Still worse is the attribution of such weakness to the gods; as when the goddesses say, 'Alas!

question: This is, perhaps, a one-sided but not wholly untrue picture of the [MASK] and practice of mankind when they 'sit down together at an assembly ,' either in ancient or modern times.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The individual becomes one with his order; or, if he resists, the world is too much for him, and will sooner or later be revenged on him.
next_sentence: When the higher natures are corrupted by politics, the lower take possession of the vacant place of philosophy.

question: that different natures ought to have different pursuits, and that [MASK]'s and women's natures are different.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: We acknowledged--did we not?
next_sentence: And now what are we saying?--that different natures ought to have the same pursuits,--this is the inconsistency which is charged upon us.

question: The artist will do nothing until he has made a tabula rasa; on this he will inscribe the constitution of a state, glancing often at the divine truth of nature, and from that deriving the [MASK] among men, mingling the two elements, rubbing out and painting in, until there is a perfect harmony or fusion of the divine and human.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But what will be the process of delineation?'
next_sentence: But perhaps the world will doubt the existence of such an artist.

question: In the strictest of all [MASK], he said.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: I shall not make the attempt, my dear man; but to avoid any misunderstanding occurring between us in future, let me ask, in what sense do you speak of a ruler or stronger whose interest, as you were saying, he being the superior, it is just that the inferior should execute--is he a ruler in the popular or in the strict sense of the term?
next_sentence: And now cheat and play the informer if you can; I ask no quarter at your hands.

question: Any more than they can be rhapsodists and [MASK] at once?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Yes, I did; and you are right in thinking that the same persons cannot succeed in both.
next_sentence: True.

question: That, he said, is a [MASK] suspicion of yours.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: I am sure, I said, that he who does not know how the beautiful and the just are likewise good will be but a sorry guardian of them; and I suspect that no one who is ignorant of the good will have a true knowledge of them.
next_sentence: And if we only have a guardian who has this knowledge our State will be perfectly ordered?

question: Did you ever [MASK] that the objects of sight imply a faculty of sight which is the most complex and costly of our senses, requiring not only objects of sense, but also a medium, which is light; without which the sight will not distinguish between colours and all will be a blank?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: You remember our old distinction of the many beautiful and the one beautiful, the particular and the universal, the objects of sight and the objects of thought?
next_sentence: For light is the noble bond between the perceiving faculty and the thing perceived, and the god who gives us light is the sun, who is the eye of the day, but is not to be confounded with the eye of man.

question: Thus liberty, when out of all [MASK] and reason, passes into the worst form of servitude ...
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And the people have jumped from the fear of slavery into slavery, out of the smoke into the fire.
next_sentence: In the previous books Plato has described the ideal State; now he returns to the perverted or declining forms, on which he had lightly touched at the end of Book IV.

question: But there is another [MASK] of character who will narrate anything, and, the worse he is, the more unscrupulous he will be; nothing will be too bad for him: and he will be ready to imitate anything, not as a joke, but in right good earnest, and before a large company.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Certainly, he said; that is the model which such a speaker must necessarily take.
next_sentence: As I was just now saying, he will attempt to represent the roll of thunder, the noise of wind and hail, or the creaking of wheels, and pulleys, and the various sounds of flutes, pipes, trumpets, and all sorts of instruments: he will bark like a dog, bleat like a sheep, or crow like a cock; his entire art will consist in imitation of voice and gesture, and there will be very little narration.

question: He refuses to answer, as if intending by the refusal to intimate that the state of knowledge which then existed was not such as would allow the philosopher to enter into his final [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But when, after having arrived at the idea of good, which is the end of the science of dialectic, he is asked, What is the nature, and what are the divisions of the science?
next_sentence: The previous sciences must first be studied, and will, we may add, continue to be studied tell the end of time, although in a sense different from any which Plato could have conceived.

question: Though unable to give a complete answer to them, we may show--first, that his views [MASK] naturally out of the circumstances of his age; and secondly, we may elicit the truth as well as the error which is contained in them.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Why Plato, who was himself a poet, and whose dialogues are poems and dramas, should have been hostile to the poets as a class, and especially to the dramatic poets; why he should not have seen that truth may be embodied in verse as well as in prose, and that there are some indefinable lights and shadows of human life which can only be expressed in poetry--some elements of imagination which always entwine with reason; why he should have supposed epic verse to be inseparably associated with the impurities of the old Hellenic mythology; why he should try Homer and Hesiod by the unfair and prosaic test of utility,--are questions which have always been debated amongst students of Plato.
next_sentence: He is the enemy of the poets because poetry was declining in his own lifetime, and a theatrocracy, as he says in the Laws, had taken the place of an intellectual aristocracy.

question: On the other hand, those steadfast natures which can better be depended upon, which in a battle are impregnable to [MASK] and immovable, are equally immovable when there is anything to be learned; they are always in a torpid state, and are apt to yawn and go to sleep over any intellectual toil.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Very true, he said.
next_sentence: Quite true.

question: And there is no reason to suppose that less care is required in the marriage of human [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: 'Certainly.'
next_sentence: But then our rulers must be skilful physicians of the State, for they will often need a strong dose of falsehood in order to bring about desirable unions between their subjects.

question: We were to [MASK] at these in order that we might judge of our own happiness and unhappiness according to the standard which they exhibited and the degree in which we resembled them, but not with any view of showing that they could exist in fact.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: We were enquiring into the nature of absolute justice and into the character of the perfectly just, and into injustice and the perfectly unjust, that we might have an ideal.
next_sentence: True, he said.

question: For children can only be [MASK] up in families.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: It never occurred to him that the greater part of them, according to universal experience, would have perished.
next_sentence: There is a subtle sympathy between the mother and the child which cannot be supplied by other mothers, or by 'strong nurses one or more' (Laws).

question: Glaucon is more demonstrative, and generally [MASK] the game.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: )...The character of Adeimantus is deeper and graver, and the profounder objections are commonly put into his mouth.
next_sentence: Adeimantus pursues the argument further.

question: Yes, he said, the purpose of the [MASK] is manifest.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And this is clearly seen to be the intention of the law, which is the ally of the whole city; and is seen also in the authority which we exercise over children, and the refusal to let them be free until we have established in them a principle analogous to the constitution of a state, and by cultivation of this higher element have set up in their hearts a guardian and ruler like our own, and when this is done they may go their ways.
next_sentence: From what point of view, then, and on what ground can we say that a man is profited by injustice or intemperance or other baseness, which will make him a worse man, even though he acquire money or power by his wickedness?

question: Evil only should be the subject of [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: All is habit: people have at last found out that the exposure is better than the concealment of the person, and now they laugh no more.
next_sentence: The first question is, whether women are able either wholly or partially to share in the employments of men.

question: Or the horseman by his art [MASK] them bad horsemen?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Certainly not.
next_sentence: Impossible.

question: Such men in their early days live with flatterers, and they themselves flatter others, in order to gain their ends; but they soon discard their followers when they have no longer any need of them; they are always either masters or servants ,--the [MASK] of friendship are unknown to them.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: If the people yield, well and good, but, if they resist, then, as before he beat his father and mother, so now he beats his fatherland and motherland, and places his mercenaries over them.
next_sentence: And they are utterly treacherous and unjust, if the nature of justice be at all understood by us.

question: And may we not [MASK] of the philosopher that he is a lover, not of a part of wisdom only, but of the whole?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The whole.
next_sentence: Yes, of the whole.

question: Let us then consider, first of all, what will be their way of [MASK], now that we have thus established them.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: I dare say that you are right in your suggestion, I said; we had better think the matter out, and not shrink from the enquiry.
next_sentence: Will they not produce corn, and wine, and clothes, and shoes, and build houses for themselves?

question: He must have money, no matter how, if he is to [MASK] horrid pains and pangs.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Yes, that is sure to be the case.
next_sentence: He must.

question: The evil is certainly not prevented there; for oligarchies have both the extremes of great wealth and utter [MASK].
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Yes, that is an evil which also first begins in this State.
next_sentence: True.

question: Our former education had two branches, gymnastic, which was occupied with the body, and music, the sister art, which infused a natural harmony into mind and literature; but neither of these sciences gave any [MASK] of doing what we want.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And what training will draw the soul upwards?
next_sentence: Nothing remains to us but that universal or primary science of which all the arts and sciences are partakers, I mean number or calculation.

question: The intention was, that, in the case of the [MASK] generally, each individual should be put to the use for which nature intended him, one to one work, and then every man would do his own business, and be one and not many; and so the whole city would be one and not many.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And the other, said I, of which we were speaking before is lighter still,--I mean the duty of degrading the offspring of the guardians when inferior, and of elevating into the rank of guardians the offspring of the lower classes, when naturally superior.
next_sentence: Yes, he said; that is not so difficult.

question: Then you will make a law that they shall have such an education as will enable them to [MASK] the greatest skill in asking and answering questions?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Certainly not.
next_sentence: Yes, he said, you and I together will make it.

question: Then, besides other [MASK], we must try to find a naturally well-proportioned and gracious mind, which will move spontaneously towards the true being of everything.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: To proportion.
next_sentence: Certainly.

question: But what do you [MASK] by the highest of all knowledge?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Yes, he said, you are quite right in testing him.
next_sentence: You may remember, I said, that we divided the soul into three parts; and distinguished the several natures of justice, temperance, courage, and wisdom?

question: The [MASK] is escaped by the unmeaning evasion: for though his real and apparent interests may differ, what the ruler thinks to be his interest will always remain what he thinks to be his interest.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Thrasymachus is saved from this speedy downfall by his disciple Cleitophon, who introduces the word 'thinks;'--not the actual interest of the ruler, but what he thinks or what seems to be his interest, is justice.
next_sentence: Of course this was not the original assertion, nor is the new interpretation accepted by Thrasymachus himself.

question: What then is the [MASK] object of them?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Neither are the two arts of music and gymnastic really designed, as is often supposed, the one for the training of the soul, the other for the training of the body.
next_sentence: I believe, I said, that the teachers of both have in view chiefly the improvement of the soul.

question: If the helm is [MASK] them, they drug the captain's posset, bind him hand and foot, and take possession of the ship.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: The sailors want to steer, although they know nothing of the art; and they have a theory that it cannot be learned.
next_sentence: He who joins in the mutiny is termed a good pilot and what not; they have no conception that the true pilot must observe the winds and the stars, and must be their master, whether they like it or not;--such an one would be called by them fool, prater, star-gazer.

question: And the same holds of the ear as well as of the eye, of poetry as [MASK] as painting.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But which of them is true is determined by the art of calculation; and this is allied to the better faculty in the soul, as the arts of imitation are to the worse.
next_sentence: The imitation is of actions voluntary or involuntary, in which there is an expectation of a good or bad result, and present experience of pleasure and pain.

question: [MASK] us assume then that they are pacified.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: 'They will be less disposed to quarrel.'
next_sentence: Still, a person may hesitate about the probability of the son of a king being a philosopher.

question: The ruin of oligarchy is the ruin of democracy; the same disease magnified and intensified by liberty overmasters democracy--the truth being that the excessive increase of anything often causes a reaction in the opposite direction; and this is the case not only in the seasons and in [MASK] and animal life, but above all in forms of government.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But what is the next step?
next_sentence: True.

question: Will not their eyes be dazzled, and will they not try to get away from the [MASK] to something which they are able to behold without blinking?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Suppose now that you suddenly turn them round and make them look with pain and grief to themselves at the real images; will they believe them to be real?
next_sentence: And suppose further, that they are dragged up a steep and rugged ascent into the presence of the sun himself, will not their sight be darkened with the excess of light?

question: Are not the chief elements of temperance, speaking generally, obedience to commanders and self-control in sensual [MASK]?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Certainly.
next_sentence: True.

question: For this is he who is able to make not only [MASK] of every kind, but plants and animals, himself and all other things--the earth and heaven, and the things which are in heaven or under the earth; he makes the gods also.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Wait a little, and there will be more reason for your saying so.
next_sentence: He must be a wizard and no mistake.

question: None of them will have anything specially his or her own; they will be together, and will be [MASK] up together, and will associate at gymnastic exercises.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: You, I said, who are their legislator, having selected the men, will now select the women and give them to them;--they must be as far as possible of like natures with them; and they must live in common houses and meet at common meals.
next_sentence: And so they will be drawn by a necessity of their natures to have intercourse with each other--necessity is not too strong a word, I think?

question: That is to [MASK], justice is useful when money is useless?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Precisely.
next_sentence: That is the inference.

question: Then let us have a clear [MASK], and not be satisfied with half an explanation.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Yes.
next_sentence: Proceed.

question: He would not harass them with minute regulations, he would have allowed some changes in the laws: but not changes which would affect the fundamental institutions of the state, such for example as would [MASK] an aristocracy into a timocracy, or a timocracy into a popular form of government.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Plato hopes to preserve in a later generation the mind of the legislator; he would have his citizens remain within the lines which he has laid down for them.
next_sentence: Passing from speculations to facts, we observe that progress has been the exception rather than the law of human history.

question: And so we arrive at the result, that the pleasure of the intelligent part of the soul is the pleasantest of the three, and that he of us in whom this is the ruling [MASK] has the pleasantest life.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But since experience and wisdom and reason are the judges--  The only inference possible, he replied, is that pleasures which are approved by the lover of wisdom and reason are the truest.
next_sentence: Unquestionably, he said, the wise man speaks with authority when he approves of his own life.

question: The world began again after a [MASK] and was reconstructed out of the fragments of itself.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Tradition told them of many destructions of mankind and of the preservation of a remnant.
next_sentence: Also they were acquainted with empires of unknown antiquity, like the Egyptian or Assyrian; but they had never seen them grow, and could not imagine, any more than we can, the state of man which preceded them.

question: The expression really means that the [MASK] principle in a man masters the worse.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Some light is thrown upon the nature of this virtue by the popular description of a man as 'master of himself'--which has an absurd sound, because the master is also the servant.
next_sentence: There are in cities whole classes--women, slaves and the like--who correspond to the worse, and a few only to the better; and in our State the former class are held under control by the latter.

question: But, if he carries on the softening and soothing process, in the next stage he begins to melt and waste, until he has wasted away his spirit and cut out the sinews of his soul; and he becomes a [MASK] warrior.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And, when a man allows music to play upon him and to pour into his soul through the funnel of his ears those sweet and soft and melancholy airs of which we were just now speaking, and his whole life is passed in warbling and the delights of song; in the first stage of the process the passion or spirit which is in him is tempered like iron, and made useful, instead of brittle and useless.
next_sentence: Very true.

question: The really excellent gymnastic is twin [MASK] of that simple music which we were just now describing.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: That is my view.
next_sentence: How so?

question: Yes, he said, you are quite right in [MASK] him.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Then the aspirant must not only be tested in those labours and dangers and pleasures which we mentioned before, but there is another kind of probation which we did not mention--he must be exercised also in many kinds of knowledge, to see whether the soul will be able to endure the highest of all, or will faint under them, as in any other studies and exercises.
next_sentence: But what do you mean by the highest of all knowledge?

question: All his desires are absorbed in the [MASK] of wisdom, which is the love of truth.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: He has the noblest gifts of nature, and makes the highest use of them.
next_sentence: None of the graces of a beautiful soul are wanting in him; neither can he fear death, or think much of human life.

question: And will the habit of body of our ordinary athletes be [MASK] to them?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Yes, he said.
next_sentence: Why not?

question: They must be [MASK] requested not to abuse hell; they may be reminded that their stories are both untrue and discouraging.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: There is another motive in purifying religion, which is to banish fear; for no man can be courageous who is afraid of death, or who believes the tales which are repeated by the poets concerning the world below.
next_sentence: Nor must they be angry if we expunge obnoxious passages, such as the depressing words of Achilles--'I would rather be a serving-man than rule over all the dead;' and the verses which tell of the squalid mansions, the senseless shadows, the flitting soul mourning over lost strength and youth, the soul with a gibber going beneath the earth like smoke, or the souls of the suitors which flutter about like bats.

question: It was agreed that they were to be lovers of their country, and were to be tested in the [MASK]'s fire of pleasures and pains, and those who came forth pure and remained fixed in their principles were to have honours and rewards in life and after death.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: I will be wiser now and acknowledge that we must go to the bottom of another question: What is to be the education of our guardians?
next_sentence: But at this point, the argument put on her veil and turned into another path.

question: Looking into the orb of [MASK], he sees nothing, but he is warmed and elevated.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: But we may observe, that while he is aware of the vacancy of his own ideal, he is full of enthusiasm in the contemplation of it.
next_sentence: The Hebrew prophet believed that faith in God would enable him to govern the world; the Greek philosopher imagined that contemplation of the good would make a legislator.

question: The same natures must still be chosen, and the [MASK] again given to the surest and the bravest, and, if possible, to the fairest; and, having noble and generous tempers, they should also have the natural gifts which will facilitate their education.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Certainly, he said.
next_sentence: And what are these?

question: 'Do you ask whether [MASK] and comedy are to be admitted? '
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: These are the three styles--which of them is to be admitted into our State?
next_sentence: Yes, but also something more--Is it not doubtful whether our guardians are to be imitators at all?

question: For no man who is worthy to be called a [MASK] would ever submit to such an agreement if he were able to resist; he would be mad if he did.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: This they affirm to be the origin and nature of justice;--it is a mean or compromise, between the best of all, which is to do injustice and not be punished, and the worst of all, which is to suffer injustice without the power of retaliation; and justice, being at a middle point between the two, is tolerated not as a good, but as the lesser evil, and honoured by reason of the inability of men to do injustice.
next_sentence: Such is the received account, Socrates, of the nature and origin of justice.

question: This latter regulation applies to those who are within the [MASK] ages, after which they may range at will, provided they avoid the prohibited degrees of parents and children, or of brothers and sisters, which last, however, are not absolutely prohibited, if a dispensation be procured.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Any one above or below those ages who partakes in the hymeneals shall be guilty of impiety; also every one who forms a marriage connexion at other times without the consent of the rulers.
next_sentence: 'But how shall we know the degrees of affinity, when all things are common?'

question: But as all are of the same original [MASK], a golden parent will sometimes have a silver son, or a silver parent a golden son.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Some of you have the power of command, and in the composition of these he has mingled gold, wherefore also they have the greatest honour; others he has made of silver, to be auxiliaries; others again who are to be husbandmen and craftsmen he has composed of brass and iron; and the species will generally be preserved in the children.
next_sentence: And God proclaims as a first principle to the rulers, and above all else, that there is nothing which they should so anxiously guard, or of which they are to be such good guardians, as of the purity of the race.

question: How can they, he [MASK], if they are blind and cannot see?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Well, and can the eyes fulfil their end if they are wanting in their own proper excellence and have a defect instead?
next_sentence: You mean to say, if they have lost their proper excellence, which is sight; but I have not arrived at that point yet.

question: That they must abstain from intoxication has been already remarked by us; for of all [MASK] a guardian should be the last to get drunk and not know where in the world he is.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Very good.
next_sentence: Yes, he said; that a guardian should require another guardian to take care of him is ridiculous indeed.

question: Does not the practice of despoiling an enemy afford an excuse for not [MASK] the battle?
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Next as to the slain; ought the conquerors, I said, to take anything but their armour?
next_sentence: Cowards skulk about the dead, pretending that they are fulfilling a duty, and many an army before now has been lost from this love of plunder.

question: Let us [MASK] the existence of beds and tables.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: Then suppose that we begin in our old fashion, with the doctrine of universals.
next_sentence: There is one idea of a bed, or of a table, which the maker of each had in his mind when making them; he did not make the ideas of beds and tables, but he made beds and tables according to the ideas.

question: They cannot diminish, because they cannot be [MASK]; nor yet increase, for the increase of the immortal must come from something mortal, and so all would end in immortality.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And if this be true, souls will always exist in the same number.
next_sentence: Neither is the soul variable and diverse; for that which is immortal must be of the fairest and simplest composition.

question: Some time will pass before they get the habit of perceiving at all; and at first they will be able to perceive only shadows and reflections in the water; then they will [MASK] the moon and the stars, and will at length behold the sun in his own proper place as he is.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: And suppose further, that they are dragged up a steep and rugged ascent into the presence of the sun himself, will not their sight be darkened with the excess of light?
next_sentence: Last of all they will conclude:--This is he who gives us the year and the seasons, and is the author of all that we see.

question: Then now let us consider what will be their way of life, if they are to [MASK] our idea of them.
title: The Republic
prev_sentence: He must.
next_sentence: In the first place, none of them should have any property of his own beyond what is absolutely necessary; neither should they have a private house or store closed against any one who has a mind to enter; their provisions should be only such as are required by trained warriors, who are men of temperance and courage; they should agree to receive from the citizens a fixed rate of pay, enough to meet the expenses of the year and no more; and they will go to mess and live together like soldiers in a camp.
